tags: im sorry to the people who i haven't  answered yet. will get to you soon
summary: Hello! I was wondering if you have a favorite theory from the show? I would ask  if you had one from the books but I haven't...
question: Hello! I was wondering if you have a favorite theory from the show? I would ask  if you had one from the books but I haven't read all the books yet. I wouldn't mind knowing your all time favorite meta too. *Smiles*
answer:
Hi Anon! 😊

You know what anon, i have a lot of theories I love, I truly do. The biggest one so far is of course Jonsa. Now I know that might sound weird because we are in the Jonsa fandom, but untill the GA actually sees Jonsa (even though I see it) it’s still considered a theory to everyone else. As in favorite show theory though, I would have to say one I brought up awhile back with Cersei actually talking about Sansa in this scene.

Then this scene just fits even more with what I mean.

Sansa gets an invitation to Kingslanding with Cersei asking “where is she?” just makes me think the theory may be true. As for my favorite meta, it will be very hard to give a specific one because i love a lot of Jonsa metas, so it’s really hard to choose to be honest. But i can tell you the first meta i read and have always been fond of, is something @kellyvela wrote awhile back. It’s definitely one I still read over and over again, and is just written so beautifully. When it comes down to it there are so many good Jonsa meta writers out there I could never be compared to. Some of these ladies put so much focus, time, and special observations in their metas that I’m jealous to not have their patience.

Thanks for the ask!

No need to know the nAme. 
Swoon and marvel at simple things.
LOST defined life. Live in the Enchanted Forest. Love what happens in Westeros. Wish you could hang out in Rosewood with some pretty little liars. Agonize over the events in Beacon Hills. And so on. Unconditional Cut & Run, Titanic and LOTR lover. 
Proud Princess Aurora, Sansa Stark and Alison Dilaurentis supporter.

summary:
Character development:
The Hound at the Battle of the Blackwater in Season 2: [threatens to defile the corpses of anyone “with a...
body:
Character development:
The Hound at the Battle of the Blackwater in Season 2: [threatens to defile the corpses of anyone “with a clean sword.”]

Sandor Clegane in season 8, probably: The Stark girls might be pains in the arse but if anything happens to them, I’ll kill everyone on  this battlefield and then myself. Thank you for coming to my TED talk.

summary: “Well, they say that it’s easier to give a speech if you imagine the audience is in their underwear. But then I remembered that...
body:
“Well, they say that it’s easier to give a speech if you imagine the audience is in their underwear. But then I remembered that would involve imagining Baelish in his underwear. That made me realize that there are things much scarier than public speaking,”

-Sansa Stark

tags: house tully is better than you
summary: You have to love how the only reason the fandom will ever stop hating the Tullys with their "inferior trout" views for five...
body:
You have to love how the only reason the fandom will ever stop hating the Tullys with their “inferior trout” views for five whole minutes is to take away Sansa’s significance from that House and pretend it’s Arwen who is the True Tully. Because heaven forbid Sansa hold any importance in an area.

They’re seriously toddlers who only care about a toy that someone else is playing with, when any other time it sits at the bottom of the toy box.

tags: i've just been thinking about this bc sometimes discourse makes things such absolutes
i get why...just that if that's being said felt i should bring this up too
summary: I think that people misinterpret GRRM’s quotes that Sansa starts out the least sympathetic POV in AGOT. As much as I think his...
body:
I think that people misinterpret GRRM’s quotes that Sansa starts out the least sympathetic POV in AGOT. As much as I think his internalised issues show, sympathetic and unsympathetic POVs aren’t always governed by objectivity when it comes to unreliable narrators. 

You can make a terrible person seem sympathetic to the reader when clearly their actions say otherwise (and they’re as dangerous as Humbert from Lolita) because of how they justify themselves and you can make a sympathetic character seem terrible when they actually haven’t done that much wrong because they don’t face reality and misdirect blame. It’s a creative writing trick that tests the reader’s critical skills. In Sansa’s case, as much as I think Arya’s POV isn’t as reliable as people think, Sansa’s own POV also tricks the reader because she hides from the truth and it’s only later one starts realising why that’s happening on a Watsonian level (apart from the zeitgeist). She misremembers traumatic events, she doesn’t want her dreams to shatter and she has issues with Ned, like Arya does with Cat. But unlike Arya, Sansa never spells her issues out and she acts out, especially after Lady’s death and doesn’t reflect on the true roots of it. They’re laying under the surface, covered up by other things but it’s there, and you only realise it as you keep reading and re-reading. In comparison, Arya makes it easier for the reader initially.   

What flips with Ned’s death is that Sansa can’t pretend about the Lannisters anymore and misdirect blame for a number of reasons - including patriarchal expectations, Lady’s death breaking her trust in Ned and her own desire to find her place in the world. It’s his death that breaks the spell. Despite misremembering a number of other things in the future because they’re traumatic, she never forgets what the Lannisters did to Ned. She never lets herself forget that because although he didn’t explain himself completely and didn’t do a lot of things she was promised, he wanted to protect her. 

Was Sansa to blame for Ned’s death? Not exactly. She ran to Cersei because she didn’t trust Ned and she didn’t want to go back to Winterfell where there weren’t singers and the courtly life wasn’t as colourful. She was defying her father on such a scale for the first time and she didn’t go there thinking she would get him arrested. It’s honestly not that different from Lyanna running away with Rhaegar without realising the consequences and the possibility of what it could mean for her father and brothers. The only reason people don’t see it immediately is because the text keeps spelling out Arya and Lyanna parallels, but there’s a lot of phrases within AGOT that hint that Ned is focusing on the wrong daughter to repeat Lyanna’s mistake. 

It was others who wanted Ned arrested/sent to the Wall/dead. Sansa wrote those letters to save Ned and prevent a war from breaking out. She pleaded Joffrey for mercy for her father and was already thinking about convincing Joffrey to shorten Ned’s sentence after a few years of exile. If she unwittingly gave the Lannisters a heads up to trap him (after Ned anyway told Cersei what he was going to do), she did everything she could do after to save him. 

But does it matter that that horrific incident makes her realise that her actions - even if unwittingly - have impact and she has to be mindful of that? Yes. And there is weight in acknowledging that because she learns from it. 

I get why people could see it as carelessly said because people have been quick to blame a 11-12 year old’s naivety over the actual perpetrators who exploited it. The thing with GRRM is the harder questions get, the more meandering his answers become and you have to read between the lines. Again, it’s not to say his internalised issues don’t show. But he spends the rest of the series proving how wrong people were about Sansa. It’s not a redemption arc for unwittingly playing a part in Ned’s fall as much as it is a sympathising arc because of the unreliable POV(s) that convinces you otherwise before. Not that he doesn’t test the boundaries like he does with every character.

reblog.comment:

It’s not a redemption arc for unwittingly playing a part in Ned’s fall as much as it is a sympathising arc because of the unreliable POV(s) that convinces you otherwise before. Not that he doesn’t test the boundaries like he does with every character.

trail.content_raw:
I think that people misinterpret GRRM’s quotes that Sansa starts out the least sympathetic POV in AGOT. As much as I think his internalised issues show, sympathetic and unsympathetic POVs aren’t always governed by objectivity when it comes to unreliable narrators. 

You can make a terrible person seem sympathetic to the reader when clearly their actions say otherwise (and they’re as dangerous as Humbert from Lolita) because of how they justify themselves and you can make a sympathetic character seem terrible when they actually haven’t done that much wrong because they don’t face reality and misdirect blame. It’s a creative writing trick that tests the reader’s critical skills. In Sansa’s case, as much as I think Arya’s POV isn’t as reliable as people think, Sansa’s own POV also tricks the reader because she hides from the truth and it’s only later one starts realising why that’s happening on a Watsonian level (apart from the zeitgeist). She misremembers traumatic events, she doesn’t want her dreams to shatter and she has issues with Ned, like Arya does with Cat. But unlike Arya, Sansa never spells her issues out and she acts out, especially after Lady’s death and doesn’t reflect on the true roots of it. They’re laying under the surface, covered up by other things but it’s there, and you only realise it as you keep reading and re-reading. In comparison, Arya makes it easier for the reader initially.   

What flips with Ned’s death is that Sansa can’t pretend about the Lannisters anymore and misdirect blame for a number of reasons - including patriarchal expectations, Lady’s death breaking her trust in Ned and her own desire to find her place in the world. It’s his death that breaks the spell. Despite misremembering a number of other things in the future because they’re traumatic, she never forgets what the Lannisters did to Ned. She never lets herself forget that because although he didn’t explain himself completely and didn’t do a lot of things she was promised, he wanted to protect her. 

Was Sansa to blame for Ned’s death? Not exactly. She ran to Cersei because she didn’t trust Ned and she didn’t want to go back to Winterfell where there weren’t singers and the courtly life wasn’t as colourful. She was defying her father on such a scale for the first time and she didn’t go there thinking she would get him arrested. It’s honestly not that different from Lyanna running away with Rhaegar without realising the consequences and the possibility of what it could mean for her father and brothers. The only reason people don’t see it immediately is because the text keeps spelling out Arya and Lyanna parallels, but there’s a lot of phrases within AGOT that hint that Ned is focusing on the wrong daughter to repeat Lyanna’s mistake. 

It was others who wanted Ned arrested/sent to the Wall/dead. Sansa wrote those letters to save Ned and prevent a war from breaking out. She pleaded Joffrey for mercy for her father and was already thinking about convincing Joffrey to shorten Ned’s sentence after a few years of exile. If she unwittingly gave the Lannisters a heads up to trap him (after Ned anyway told Cersei what he was going to do), she did everything she could do after to save him. 

But does it matter that that horrific incident makes her realise that her actions - even if unwittingly - have impact and she has to be mindful of that? Yes. And there is weight in acknowledging that because she learns from it. 

I get why people could see it as carelessly said because people have been quick to blame a 11-12 year old’s naivety over the actual perpetrators who exploited it. The thing with GRRM is the harder questions get, the more meandering his answers become and you have to read between the lines. Again, it’s not to say his internalised issues don’t show. But he spends the rest of the series proving how wrong people were about Sansa. It’s not a redemption arc for unwittingly playing a part in Ned’s fall as much as it is a sympathising arc because of the unreliable POV(s) that convinces you otherwise before. Not that he doesn’t test the boundaries like he does with every character.
trail.content:

She misremembers traumatic events, she doesn’t want her dreams to shatter and she has issues with Ned, like Arya does with Cat. But unlike Arya, Sansa never spells her issues out and she acts out, especially after Lady’s death and doesn’t reflect on the true roots of it. They’re laying under the surface, covered up by other things but it’s there, and you only realise it as you keep reading and re-reading. In comparison, Arya makes it easier for the reader initially.   

What flips with Ned’s death is that Sansa can’t pretend about the Lannisters anymore and misdirect blame for a number of reasons - including patriarchal expectations, Lady’s death breaking her trust in Ned and her own desire to find her place in the world. It’s his death that breaks the spell. Despite misremembering a number of other things in the future because they’re traumatic, she never forgets what the Lannisters did to Ned. She never lets herself forget that because although he didn’t explain himself completely and didn’t do a lot of things she was promised, he wanted to protect her.

She ran to Cersei because she didn’t trust Ned and she didn’t want to go back to Winterfell where there weren’t singers and the courtly life wasn’t as colourful. It’s not a redemption arc for unwittingly playing a part in Ned’s fall as much as it is a sympathising arc because of the unreliable POV(s) that convinces you otherwise before. Not that he doesn’t test the boundaries like he does with every character.
